Chael Sonnen tells the story of how a routine request from Misha Parsons uncovered four bizarre search questions ‚Äî including one that would eventually shape his entire public persona. From whether tickling is legal in the UFC, to starting MMA at 27, to the only 17-year-old ever to compete in the promotion, Chael answers them all. But the final question ‚Äî about his testosterone levels ‚Äî opens the door to something much bigger. For the first time in detail, Chael explains how a false narrative spread, why defending himself only made it worse, and how he learned a brutal truth about public perception: explaining is losing. This isn‚Äôt a story about PEDs. It‚Äôs a story about psychology, media, and how reputations are formed. Chael breaks down how a single misleading claim, amplified at the wrong time by the wrong outlet, became the foundation for ‚ÄúThe Bad Guy‚Äù character ‚Äî not by design, but by survival. It‚Äôs a rare look behind the curtain at how fighters are shaped not just by wins and losses, but by headlines, silence, and restraint. Terms: sportsbook.draftkings.com/promos. Ends 2/15/26 at 11:59 PM ET. Sponsored by DK. California Baptist University has announced it is discontinuing its wrestling program. On the surface, it looks like a budget decision. In reality, it‚Äôs a warning sign. Chael Sonnen explains why this move has far bigger implications than one school or one sport. The NIL era was created to fix a real problem‚Äîthe NCAA keeping massive revenues while athletes received nothing. That imbalance needed correction. But the current system has created a new one. Money is now being funneled almost entirely into football and men‚Äôs basketball. Olympic sports‚Äîthe very programs that develop discipline, sacrifice, and long-term excellence‚Äîare being cut to make room. Wrestling is just one of the first casualties. Sonnen lays out a perspective rarely discussed: Olympic sports matter at a national level. Countries take Olympic performance seriously because it reflects something deeper‚Äîdiscipline, resilience, and the ability of young people to train, sacrifice, follow instruction, and succeed under pressure. That same age group, those same qualities, are what nations quietly measure through Olympic competition. And here‚Äôs the part many people miss: Olympic athletes do not come from training centers. They come from universities. The NCAA system feeds freestyle and Greco-Roman wrestling, track and field, gymnastics, and other Olympic disciplines. When college programs disappear, the pipeline collapses. This isn‚Äôt nostalgia. It‚Äôs infrastructure. Cal Baptist‚Äôs decision highlights a growing trend. Olympic sports are being stripped away not because they failed‚Äîbut because the system around them changed. If this continues, the damage won‚Äôt show up immediately. It will show up years later, when the pipeline is gone and can‚Äôt be rebuilt. #Wrestling #NIL #NCAA #OlympicSports #CollegeWrestling #ChaelSonnen #CombatSports #USAOlympics Bad Guy Inc merch now available at https://BadGuyInc.com Click here to subscribe: https://bit.ly/3FrHIPK Follow me on IG: https://bit.ly/3HY7BIE Follow me on Twitter: https://bit.ly/3tvY5J7 Follow me on Threads https://www.threads.com/@sonnench

Chael Sonnen believes there is exactly one fighter guaranteed a spot on the UFC White House card: Michael Chandler. Not because of rankings. Not because of wins. But because of loyalty, patience, and timing. If Chandler loses to Conor McGregor, the UFC will want to reward him. Red Panty Night is real, and Chandler earned that opportunity the hard way. He went through The Ultimate Fighter. He waited. He stayed quiet while dates, fights, and promises were dangled in front of him. Through it all, he remained a reliable company guy‚Äîand that matters more than people realize. What‚Äôs changed is the conversation. For the first time, Chandler publicly spoke about a fight that didn‚Äôt involve Conor McGregor. Instead, he talked about the BMF title and specifically mentioned Max Holloway. He even predicted Holloway would beat Charles Oliveira‚Äîthen made it clear he had his eye on that belt. That omission matters. Chandler has always talked about Conor, even when preparing for other opponents. This time, Conor wasn‚Äôt mentioned at all. Behind the scenes, things have gone quiet. McGregor‚Äôs suspension paused the conversation. Then came comments about contracts, phone calls with Ari Emanuel, and uncertainty about timelines. After doing the legwork, Sonnen says this isn‚Äôt public negotiation or chess‚Äîit‚Äôs distance. The Chandler vs. McGregor fight isn‚Äôt happening. So what do you do with Chandler? Big fights are still available. A BMF matchup fits his profile. And regardless of opponent, Sonnen is confident Chandler won‚Äôt just be on the White House card‚Äîhe‚Äôll be on the main card. Terms: sportsbook.draftkings.com/promos. Ends 2/15/26 at 11:59 PM ET. Sponsored by DK. Jon Jones didn‚Äôt announce a retirement‚Äîbut he may have said enough to take himself out of contention. In a recent conversation, Jones turned down a proposed wrestling match with Daniel Cormier under the Real American Freestyle banner. That part alone isn‚Äôt shocking. What caught attention was the explanation. Jones said he has severe arthritis in his hip and qualifies for a hip replacement. He admitted his last two training camps were a struggle and made it clear that what he has left physically matters to him‚Äîespecially with a young son at home. Officially, all Jones did was decline a wrestling match. But if the explanation is taken at face value, it raises a larger question. If Jones cannot wrestle because of his hip, what does that say about MMA? Wrestling is foundational to mixed martial arts, and the statement inevitably leads people to wonder whether Jones is still physically able‚Äîor willing‚Äîto compete at the highest level. The timing matters. Alex Pereira recently said he would not be fighting Jon Jones at the White House event, and Jones himself made no mention of fighting in this interview. Notably, he also made no reference to the White House at all‚Äîsomething he had consistently done in prior appearances. There is another interpretation. Jones may simply be preserving what he has left for one final MMA run and refusing to spend it on a wrestling camp. Waldo Cortes-Acosta floated an idea that stopped me in my tracks: it might be time for an interim heavyweight title. And the more you look at the current landscape, the harder it is to dismiss. The UFC has no clear parameters for when a champion must defend. Boxing does. Pro wrestling used to. Even other sports have timelines. But at heavyweight, we‚Äôre operating without a clock. Tom Aspinall is the undisputed champion, injured in the Octagon, and that matters. If anyone deserves patience, it‚Äôs him. This isn‚Äôt about stripping Tom. It‚Äôs about keeping the division moving while he heals. The problem is clarity. We don‚Äôt know how long Aspinall will be out, and we don‚Äôt know what the plan is. Holding everything for a Ciryl Gane rematch might sound logical, but timing matters. That first fight was the lowest-performing pay-per-view of the year, and momentum fades fast. Waiting another four or five months doesn‚Äôt help anyone‚Äîespecially the rest of the division. Here‚Äôs the bigger issue: who exactly would even fight for an interim belt? Interim titles usually exist to justify massive, unavoidable fights. At heavyweight, that fight doesn‚Äôt obviously exist. Outside of a handful of names‚Äîand one undefeated wrestler, Josh Hockett‚Äîthe division is thin. Wrestling, the most dominant skill set in MMA history, is nearly absent at heavyweight right now. Waldo‚Äôs idea isn‚Äôt wrong. It‚Äôs just incomplete. An interim belt only works if there‚Äôs a fight worthy of it. And that‚Äôs the question nobody‚Äôs answering. articles.title: Retirement? Volkanovski Said No Chance #ufc
articles.description: Alexander Volkanovski doesn‚Äôt just fight ‚Äî he outworks you, outlasts you, and somehow finds a way. Every single time. Chael Sonnen breaks down what makes Volk different. Winning one gritty fight takes heart. Doing it over and over for years? That takes a lifetime of work. And now, Volkanovski is tying Jos√© Aldo‚Äôs legendary featherweight record, putting himself in rare air among the greatest 145-pounders ever. For a moment, it felt like this might be the end. His tone was calm. Almost reflective. Like a guy who might be ready to hang them up. And honestly, if Volk had retired, nobody would‚Äôve questioned it. He‚Äôs earned that right. But then he did the opposite. Instead of walking away, Volkanovski called out Movsar Evloev and Lerone Murphy ‚Äî two of the toughest, hungriest contenders in the division. No easy fights. No victory laps. Just straight back into the fire. That tells you everything. Chael explains why that mentality separates champions from legends. Some guys protect their legacy. Volk keeps testing it. He‚Äôs not chasing comfort ‚Äî he‚Äôs chasing competition. Retirement doesn‚Äôt sound like a man calling out killers. This isn‚Äôt the end. It might be another run. #AlexanderVolkanovski #UFC #MMA #JoseAldo #MovsarEvloev #LeroneMurphy #Featherweight #ChaelSonnen

articles.title: Volk Could‚Äôve Been Double Champ #ufc
articles.description: Alexander Volkanovski was closer to becoming a double champion than people remember ‚Äî and Chael Sonnen thinks he might have actually beaten Islam Makhachev that first night. Not ‚Äúcompetitive.‚Äù Not ‚Äúmoral victory.‚Äù Chael means flat-out won. In this breakdown, Chael revisits their first lightweight title fight and explains why Volk‚Äôs performance ages better every single time we watch Islam dominate the division. Makhachev is breaking records, running through contenders, even flirting with welterweight ‚Äî and we‚Äôre supposed to forget that Volkanovski pushed him to the absolute limit? Volk clearly won two rounds. Some argue three. And when the decision came in, nobody felt certain. That‚Äôs how close it was. But here‚Äôs Chael‚Äôs key point: commitment. If Volkanovski had fully relinquished the 145-pound belt and truly moved up to 155 ‚Äî bigger camp, bigger body, fully adjusted ‚Äî maybe that tiny gap disappears. Maybe that razor-close fight flips. Maybe we‚Äôre talking about ‚Äúchamp-champ‚Äù Volk right now. Instead, he tried to do both. And at the highest level, half-measures cost you inches ‚Äî and inches cost you titles. Looking back, it might be one of the biggest ‚Äúwhat ifs‚Äù in UFC history. #AlexanderVolkanovski #IslamMakhachev #UFC #MMA #DoubleChamp #Lightweight #Featherweight #chaelsonnen
